docs.lead_paragraph: Tam Ly dresses in the image of the father he never knew, in camouflage clothing and combat boots and, for good measure, a rakish pair of black sunglasses. Born out of wedlock, nursed in a Buddhist temple in Vietnam, reared on the streets where he sold honey cakes outside the central cathedral in Ho Chi Minh City, Mr. Tam, now 23, came to the United States two years ago as part of a belated Government program to accept the offspring of American servicemen abandoned by their fathers in South Vietnam.

headline.main: Once Lost in Vietnam, Now Lost in America
